newsitem.title: USA: UN approves 35th Iraqi oil contract under accord.
newsitem.headline: UN approves 35th Iraqi oil contract under accord.

text.p: The United Nations has approved a 35th oil contract under the Iraq oil-for-food accord, U.N. sources said Friday.

The buyer of the crude was not immediately known, but was thought to be one of two companies with contracts pending from Thursday night. Sources said one of the pending contracts was for U.S. independent oil company Delta Petroleum Products.
Details of the Delta contract call for Iraq to sell 10,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude for 90 days in the second 90-day period of the six-month oil accord.

The U.N. announced Thursday that the first $1 billion in oil sales for the first 90-day period was complete, and that all future contracts would apply to the second period beginning March 10 and ending June 9.

Terms of the accord permit Baghdad to sell up to $2 billion worth of crude for food and aid purchases, as part of a humanitarian exception to economic sanctions slapped on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
